ygData.subject: Re: 3D cross product domain
ygData.msgSnippet: If you are training on only a single example and every time you switch examples it goes back to square one it sounds like the problem is overspecialization.

If you are training on only a single example and every time you switch
examples it goes back to square one it sounds like the problem is
overspecialization.  In classification tasks, you need to train on a
broad representative range of examples that every individual sees. 
Then each individual receives a score reflecting their overall
performance on the training set.  That way, you are training for
generalization.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:
> hey group, 
> I'm having a terrible time searching the space for solving a cross
> product. 
> 
> Fitness is measured by giving it six inputs, one for x,y and z for
each
> input vector, and then measuring the absolute error of each of the
three
> output components. 
> 
> Every individual is tested on two different cross products every
> generation. 
> 
> Every some number of generations ( I call ticks ) the cross product
> inputs are randomly generated, and the new correct cross product
> calculated. 
> 
> I limited the network size to 20 neurons, as I figure more than this
> would be bloat.
> 
> I've been plotting best fitness and average fitness, and it doesn't
look
> like it will ever converge on a solution (have run 4000
generations, pop
> size 128). The algorithm does it's thing before I change the inputs,
> where the error starts off big, then gets small on an asymptotic
curve,
> but it exactly the same way, over and over, every time I change the
> inputs. The average fitness looks similar, but is generally moving
down
> from bad to worse. 
> I think this should be a straight forward domain, as the math is
only
> six calculations. What am I doing wrong? 
> 
> chad
